i absolutely love this app, everything is just great. i am a student and i use this app to prepare contemporary affairs for my exams. it would be wonderful if somehow i could filter news based on location more precisely as even with location on a lot of the categories are world specific where it would be useful to have feature to filter out local news per category. thank you for the efforts, love the app!

Hi there! üòä I'm Gokula Kannan, and I just have to say that I absolutely adore this app! I've been a big fan of Flipboard for years, but after using this app for just a month, it feels like the perfect fit for me. Thank you so much! I've shared it with all my friends too. Keep up the amazing work! üöÄ I'd love to see even more improvements in line with iOS 26's new UI and features. I'll definitely let you know if any ideas pop into mind. Thanks again!

i‚Äôve only had the app shortly but i can already tell it‚Äôs an innovative and useful news app. 100% the best for me personally out of others. however a few things immediately stood out to me. i like the system to personalise what i follow however a way to directly follow a certain strain of stories would be nice. for example following everything to do with just liverpool. another feature that would be nice is a way to narrow down politics to my own country like england/uk. also this one isn‚Äôt a big deal but being able to change the language to British english would be a good quality of life update. also in the future you should 100% add a threads system under stories like twitter or instagram it would definitely boost time spent on your app and interest. keep up the good work and don‚Äôt ruin your app you have a big chance at success.

ÏÉÅÌò∏ÏûëÏö© ÏöîÏÜåÍ∞Ä ÏûàÎäî Dear Developer of Particle, I am one of your big fan so i just wanted to take a moment to thank you for creating such an incredible AI app that has transformed the way I read and process articles and news.This AI has been an invaluable tool in my daily routine, making me more efficient and enhancing my understanding of various topics. I am now studying pharmacology at univ in Korea and nearly read nothing all day for, I‚Äôve been quite busy with exams:( one day, I saw a reels introducing your app so I gave a try which turned out to be awesome!!  Best feature I particularly appreciate is the related articles and following bottons, which allows me to get to know more about the content Im interested in and get instant, accurate summaries. This has saved me a tremendous amount of time, especially when dealing with complex or lengthy articles. Your app has not only made staying informed easier but has also made the process more enjoyable. I‚Äôm truly grateful for the hard work and innovation that went into developing such an app! üëç The user-friendly interface and the option to organize my library into collections make it feel like a personal assistant tailored just for me. I‚Äôve recommended AI to several friends and they‚Äôve all been impressed by its capabilities. The question popped up my head that how does this app earn fortunes for the developers? This service is completely free and I don‚Äôt particularly see ads (for my type at least) i sincerely hope this app one day costs a heavy fee as gpt or perplexity ;( and I also want to know is there any stock related with your app that I could own cause I strongly believe this service will one day skyrocket and that would come very soon. Thank you again for your dedication to creating such a helpful tool. It‚Äôs clear that a lot of thought and effort went into making it as effective and user-friendly as possible. Best regards,-yong-

This is a game changing application. Unfortunately, it didn‚Äôt appear to reliably pull from smaller sources. As a person into mostly fringe media like gaming, mma, technology, and indie films‚Äîit seems line I only have a handful of ‚Äústories‚Äù to read on particle. Whereas my RSS setup has hundreds of articles a day‚Äîmost of which Particle has no idea about.   Seems like it‚Äôs more for actual big media journalism and such, which is cool, but that really excludes a massive chunk of the internet. I want the news that matters to me, not what you think matters to me. Could Particle potentially add some rss ingestion which then applies its magic to the hundreds of stories and turn them into dozens?   Love the app. I‚Äôm just regularly running out of stuff for it to suggest to me and having to track it down manually through the explore and search sections. There‚Äôs more in there that I want‚Äîit just isn‚Äôt being offered to me. This is after extensive training of topics I am interested in.   Thanks!

The answer is very west inclined which shows the west‚Äôs vested interested in igniting and keeping separatist movement in India via a drug-violence-political nexus *Feedback provided on question*: Request: What challenges remain in addressing Sikh separatist influence in Canada? Response: The challenges in addressing Sikh separatist influence in Canada include balancing free speech with preventing advocacy of violence, addressing the symbolic and political power of pro-Khalistan groups within the Sikh diaspora, and overcoming the legacy of past tensions between India and Canada. Additionally, both nations need to build trust and engage in consistent action on counter-extremism while navigating the broader geopolitical and domestic political dynamics that influence this issue. It appears this has become a front-page story on the app for Politics followers despite only being written about in three articles, two of which are from the same source. I don‚Äôt expect everything to be in line with my beliefs, but this in particular seems much too skewed to warrant a front-page and notification headline.  *Feedback provided on cluster*: CNN and MSNBC Call Ongoing Anti-ICE Riots ‚ÄòMostly Peaceful‚Äô Despite Widespread Violence (_Updated 3h ago_)

Hi there, i really enjoy the app from a usability and features perspective. However In Germany it appears that in Germany only a few news outlets are used as sources. For example i really see Tagesschau ZDF or like that.

At present, adjusting the frequency is not particularly intuitive. The issue arises when searching for specific subcategories, as they appear multiple times within the list. It becomes unclear for which instance the priority should be increased. (For example, I wish to see more content related to German ice hockey but ‚ÄûEishockey‚Äú appeared in like 10 categories and i don‚Äôt know the difference.)
It would be great to have all the options for the news summary in the target language, like German. For example, I want the summary, ELI5 format, controversial views translated automatically as well.

In particular for Germany, there are numerous media sources (such as Tagesschau, ZDF, LTO, etc.) that are not yet included. It would maybe even be beneficial to include an option to add your own news sources.
Would be nice to have a somewhat timeline-like view or something at all that makes it possible to see whether you have already read a news article or not.

This answer fails to include critical contextual information about the circumstances surrounding Abrego Garcia‚Äôs arrival in the US, as well as the role of US immigration policy in preventing others like him from obtaining legal recognition as asylum seekers, residents, citizens, etc.  Abrego was sent here by his family when he was just 16 years old. By definition, he couldn‚Äôt have made the choice to cross the US-Mx border illegally. He was too young at the time - at least according to US law - to live on his own without a parent or guardian, let alone undertake a project like traveling from El Salvador through Mexico, into Texas, and then onto Maryland independently. Of note, his status as a minor child barred him from making other independent decisions - including, say, obtaining legal representation to pursue an asylum case - after he arrived. While some might want to argue that he should have hired an attorney the moment he turned 18, I respectfully ask that they take an afternoon to research the options he had available to him at that time and then ask themselves what they would have done differently- or expected their 18-year-old son to do - under similar circumstances. Without these additions, this answer is harmful.  *Feedback provided on question*: Request: Did Garcia come to the us leagally? Response: No, Garcia entered the U.S. illegally. Hi! I noticed a small rendering artifact when tapping on a story in the main feed. The story scales down on touch-down, and during the scale animation there‚Äôs a hairline seam that becomes visible. This is likely a SwiftUI issue where both the top and bottom views are being scaled independently during the scale effect, and because their heights are rounded, it‚Äôs falling on different pixels and causing a seam.  You can fix this by wrapping the body of the button in a .compositingGroup().  I‚Äôm happy to send a recording via email. A half baked idea:  I sometimes get nostalgic for how scannable news used to be on Twitter and think wouldn't it be cool if I could have my Particle notifications in a timeline/feed I could scroll through with links to the stories.  But then... what if there were personas for broader topics and entities that the notifications fell under (eg. @popcrave for the Celebrities topic, or @macrumors for Apple news). The headline could be through a "persona" completion, like what we for the Gen-Z and Energetic Rambling translations.  But then... for trending stories, what if there were a few rando personas that replied in-thread with "personalized translations" of the points from opposite sides, or the five W's. Or that posted quotes and pictures from the story. Or asked one of the suggested questions, which was answered by the OP.  It would be bizarre, since it's all synthesized... But we're used to tweets that are messy, and ephemeral, and bot-influenced so it might feel familiar. It'd be interesting to see how features appear through the lens of a social timeline, for example material updates as quote tweets.  Anyway, tl;dr I've got some experiments to play around with in Quantum. :slightly_smiling_face:

Just wanted to share a great experience for me.   Hopped in the car to go grab some dinner. Threw up my feed. Hyper niche news elevated to an experience previously reserved for only the most general news. Felt very futuristic.   It‚Äôs nice to have moments like this where thousands of pieces of work over the last year come together to deliver an experience I value and couldn‚Äôt have with anything other than particle.   Pat ya‚Äôlls selves on your respective backs.

I personally had a kind of neat affirming experience this morning.  This morning i went straight to reddit, not totally uncommon. But in my ‚Äústill laying in bed passive scrolling‚Äù i definitely ran across a few news stories that i was definitely interested in, but absolutely didn‚Äôt tap into. I‚Äôm guessing because the difficulty of extracting information i would find valuable after going into these links, via comments or the root link itself, was predicted to be not worth the effort. But whatever, kept scrolling, memes, whatever.  Then a little later opening Particle and scrolling through and easily running into a few of the same stories, i was able to link them together very easily, i knew they were about the same thing. But immediately tapped in, nbd, because i knew that next level of cursory info that i really wanted was so easy and right there. Didn‚Äôt realize i‚Äôd done it until it had already happened.  Felt very visceral on Particle delivering something i wanted in reddit and couldn‚Äôt get. And also noting that the pairing of those activities together was decent as well. The fact that i browsed reddit first actually enhanced my particle experience.  Just thought i‚Äôd note it down.

Fun anecdote from <@U07336L1761>:  He's been friends for a long time with the director of The Acolyte. He follows The Acolyte KGE with push notifications. Receiving one of these pushes will often spur an exchange with the director, and he's starting to feel like the front line on their PR team because he's often aware of coverage before anyone on her team is :sparkles:  As an aside, he also follows Elden Ring with notifications. The other day, there was a cluster about both the director and the game, so he got a push referencing that both of them were in the news about the same story. It was a delightful surprise you couldn't really get anywhere else at the moment.

met with <https://www.linkedin.com/in/maxmullen/|Max Mullen> this morning who has become a ~DAU in the last little bit. he loves the app.  some feedback he had: ‚Ä¢ He noted that the feed was feeling increasingly better. I showed him some of the content preferences and (he didn't know about it before) and KGE adding / notifications. We already know this but having some tips will really help with education here. ‚Ä¢ He asked why we've never asked him about his preferences - I told him a new NUX was coming :slightly_smiling_face:  ‚Ä¢ He had a couple of feature requests:     ‚ó¶ He wants some opt-in way to know what his friends are reading. I asked if he saw that as a follow model, double-opt-in follow, etc. He said he knows that the mechanics around that could be challenging to get right, so ignoring that (lol), he just wants a very low friction way to know what his friends are reading, and be able to blast out that he read something he thinks his friends should read. He said this is his number 1 request.     ‚ó¶ Some granular controls (which, unlike the first bullet point, nobody has ever done btw). He showed an example of a story about Prince Harry's association with Nigeria (idk I didn't look deep into it). He was like, look....I don't give a shit about Prince Harry. BUT! If Prince Harry was IN SANFRANCISCO, yeah I would care, a lot. So as a result, I don't want to say "less like this" on the Prince Harry story because I don't know the effect it would have.         ‚ñ™Ô∏é I tried to show an example of a video game story about God of War, and do a demo where I could go into topic preferences and say, "More Video Games" but "Less God of War" to explain how we have some building blocks around this granularity. Unfortunately, I spent a minute expanding and collapsing the topics (from the 3 dots) and could not find God of War in it at all. So all to say, in practice, the ease of being able to fulfill on the promise of "yes video games but no God of War" feels close but still a little out of reach. ‚Ä¢ We talked about business model / publisher payouts / etc and he was very excited about all the thinking we're doing in that arena.

Day 1 feedback from my friend Joseph:  Particle.news is super cool, thank you for giving me access!  Being able to ask questions in the context of the article is game changing. For instance I asked what were the odds of rapid unscheduled disassembly of the Boeing crewed astronaut mission and it gave me the expected risk and NASA‚Äôs limits along with sources. It‚Äôs a whole new way to interact with this information :clap:  The Explain it like I‚Äôm 5 module and a couple others are really handy, but many of the modules aren‚Äôt relevant to my interests, it would be great to be able to sort or curate them. Maybe even auto apply some to every article I read?   Even the preferences screen is new and fresh to me, I didn‚Äôt know you could do all that in iOS preferences. The only bummer for me is the ability to select zodiac sign, I know people like astrology but it makes the experience seem cheaper to me  This is a great product and I‚Äôm looking forward to using it as my news interface this week!

quick summary of some user feedback from alberto (former Twitter pm, good friend)  *Overall* ‚Ä¢ love the app, use it all the time, audio is my favorite feature, i listen in the evenings with my girlfriend Stories & For You: ‚Ä¢ Topic groupings are confusing, I still see many of the same topics not grouped. Like I'll see 4 trump stories in a row and then something that says " 10 more trump stories" ‚Ä¢ Entities (he's referring to KGEs) are meh. The things I want to know about aren't always an entity and the ones I see are usually obvious. They're cool I guess. I never really care about the related stories in there. ‚Ä¢ I like the political spectrum thing. But most of the time the story is balanced so it's not interesting. (Sara's note:....working as intended? lol) ‚Ä¢ Sports. I never care about sports beyond the final score. I'll only click in if something absolutely crazy has happened. But normally I just want the score and maybe the title and to move on. ‚Ä¢ LOVE LOCATION BASED. I want to filter by location. When it's nearby I always want to tap on it. ‚Ä¢ The modules are cool, but sometimes they are out of scope of the story and don't make sense. Search / Trending ‚Ä¢ Search is good. I use it and it works for me when I want to know about something I heard elsewhere and just get the summary. Audio: ‚Ä¢ Favorite part of the app (Sara's note: he's referring to generated podcast) ‚Ä¢ I love listening to it at 6pm and getting the like, "wtf happened today". ‚Ä¢ The intro and outro is too long, too repetitive and cheesy. "Today we learned about blah blah". And it's hard to skip. If it was short I wouldn't care but it's too long. ‚Ä¢ I want push notifications to tell me when my evening podcast is ready.  ‚Ä¢ I want to be able to deep dive on a story when I hear about it, instead of having to scroll or search for it. Commenting: ‚Ä¢ I don't care about comments but my girlfriend does. I don't even read them. But my girlfriend wants to read comments so I can ask her more about that. what do you think this is? 2022?

Here‚Äôs a summary of the key points: 1. Overwhelm and Volume: Many feel overwhelmed by the sheer volume of news available, finding it hard to sift through vast amounts of content and decide what to read. 2. Bias and Objectivity: Concerns about bias in news reporting are prevalent. People are seeking unbiased, fact-based reporting but often find it difficult to identify or access. 3. Clickbait and Sensationalism: Clickbait headlines and sensationalist content are frustrating for those seeking straightforward news. This often leads to disappointment when the content doesn‚Äôt match the headline or lacks depth. 4. Fragmentation and Disaggregation: The distribution of news across various platforms and sources makes it challenging to find consolidated, relevant news. This is compounded by different platforms catering to specific interests (like tech, politics, food). 5. Paywalls and Access: Paywalls are a significant barrier, preventing access to full articles and quality content. Readers are looking for a balance between supporting journalism and having free access to information. 6. Personalization and Relevance: There is a desire for news that is personalized and relevant to individual interests and needs, but current systems often fail to deliver this effectively. 7. Quality and Depth of Reporting: Concerns about the declining quality of journalism, with an emphasis on quantity over in-depth, investigative reporting. 8. Social Media and Algorithm Challenges: The changing nature of platforms like Twitter and the dissatisfaction with algorithm-driven content feeds lead to challenges in finding timely and relevant news. 9. Local News Accessibility: Difficulty in accessing local news that‚Äôs relevant and detailed, especially in a format that‚Äôs easy to navigate and free from overwhelming information. 10. Time and Efficiency: People are looking for ways to consume news more efficiently, preferring summaries and digests that save time while still providing comprehensive coverage. 11. Misinformation and Trust: Discerning trustworthy sources and accurate information is a growing concern, especially with the proliferation of misinformation. 12. Navigational and UX Issues: Poor user experience on news websites and apps, including intrusive ads and bad interface design, hinders the news-reading experience. 13. Desire for Diverse Perspectives: There‚Äôs an interest in receiving news from multiple viewpoints to gain a more rounded understanding of events, but this is often hard to achieve with current news sources. Overall, people are seeking a news experience that is efficient, unbiased, comprehensive, and tailored to their interests, without being bogged down by sensationalism, paywalls, and poor user experiences. More feedback, from another iOS Engineer at Apple. Nothing crazy here, but a few supporting ideas.  The takeaway i had is that we have an opportunity in Communications/Marketing/Product Features to explain to people WHY they should even want a news app. Why it improves their lives. I think we all on the team know that being current even informed is value. But its interesting to think about how we convince people who doesn‚Äôt intuitively feel that way. Not that we have to, there is still a big market. Just an interesting thought.

Re: ‚ÄúGood Hierarchy‚Äù comment from my grandfather  He has given this feedback a few times, and i wanted to ask what it actually meant.  When he has been saying this is he saying that his current For You feed is in a good order than he agrees with. ‚ÄúImportant articles arranged in relative order of importance‚Äù is what he told me. But he does mean STORIES, not articles within a story.  Obviously we aren‚Äôt being super clever here, just riding on recency and article velocity. But i thought i‚Äôd mention what he means by this.  This also is reflective of something i‚Äôve heard from a few people that think the main feed should be ordered more on importance(like news apps) than on recency(social paradigm). Obviously we need both. And i think we are heading in the right direction. But i thought this was useful context.

User: nick Story: Trump Disqualified from Colorado's 2024 Primary Ballot; Appeal to U.S. Supreme Court Announced Link: <https://particlenews.ai/alpha/cluster?url_cluster_id=940825> Feedback: Great Particle moment. Newsweek is a publication I would never seek out. In context of the cluster, one of their articles stood out, and was a good read.   They had a video+caption version of the article content playing over the text, and the video content looked like it was output from a generative image model. Which led me to their AI policy which I thought was interesting and worth sharing. Seems quite AI forward to me. I liked their accountability statement. And specifically no AI images or video that appear ‚Äúlifelike‚Äù which struck me as an interesting distinction!  ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE  As Newsweek evaluates AI-based tools that might help reporters, video editors, copy editors, assignment editors and others do their jobs more effectively, we will roll them out to the newsroom. Sometimes these tools will be deployed to small teams as experiments. These experiments will always be bound by the rules in this policy.  Newsweek believes that AI tools can help journalists work faster, smarter and more creatively. Sometimes, a tool will take away the more burdensome tasks of day-to-day journalism. In other cases, AI may put a project that was too time-consuming or expensive to pursue within our newsroom's grasp. We firmly believe that soon all journalists will be working with AI in some form and we want our newsroom to embrace these technologies as quickly as is possible in an ethical way.  AI is not accountable to Newsweek readers: we are. The burden of ensuring that all stories or other content meets Newsweek standards rests with our writers, editors and producers, always.  To that end, we will always comply with the following rules when working with AI:  IMAGES  Newsweek will avoid publishing AI generated images - either video or still pictures - that appear lifelike.  WRITTEN CONTENT - CORE FUNCTIONS  If a piece of written content involves the use of AI tools in writing, research, editing or other core journalism functions, three or more journalists should be involved in producing the story‚Äîan assigning editor, a reporter and a publishing editor.  WRITTEN CONTENT - SUPPORTING FUNCTIONS  The rules requiring the involvement of three journalists does not apply when AI tools are simply used to support a journalist's work such as for note taking, transcription and video script writing, writing social copy, A/B testing headlines, adding metadata or selecting images. However, the journalist using such tools will be responsible for ensuring they do not give rise to errors.  DISCLOSURE  Any journalist using any AI tool on a core journalism function must disclose that to their editor and the publishing desk. Any tool not previously used by Newsweek must be approved by the Standards Editor
